nodes.bodyText: nit: This says "fileWideComputation", but it's really "perStartupComputation". It's not done once per file, it's done once per class initialization.
nit: I thought we had settled on logging this over wrapping in RuntimeException (@lesv FYI)
Will fix this more broadly.
This isn't static, or final. (nit: Also I almost always see it called just gson)
Will fix this more broadly.

response.getWriter() is stubbed in the tests, and expects a BufferedWriter (not a PrintWriter).
(I tried using new BufferedWriter(printWriter), but those stubs didn't produce any output in the tests.)
Thanks - done.
this should go into the LazyGlobalHolder class
Thanks - done.
this should be LazyGlobalHolder.getInstance()
Thanks - done.
what is this used for? in generally we should have no dependency on the servlet api

nodes.bodyText: good catch!
spotbugs 🙂

Can you be more specific?
Is there a form of mitigation?
Should you even be catching this?  (rather than providing a warning it might happen and let it propagate)

Switched to a LOGGER.log() format that allows printing the entire exception.
("catching this and letting it propagate" is probably the right answer, but will not compile without a cast to RuntimeException due to this issue until the release is updated)
This isn't needed and actually makes things difficult for us.

nodes.bodyText: i would keep it. it's really standard.

nodes.bodyText: As @kurtisvg mentioned in the doc, we used to do this everywhere, users got confused and it created problems.  Getting rid of it increased CSAT.

@@ -0,0 +1,49 @@

nodes.bodyText:
i think... this comment was in the context of the <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> line, which was then removed from the poms.
https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/java-docs-samples/blob/9be4e4d0de95f74a5b237d6de498cb579fc3f762/functions/imagemagick/pom.xml
to be clear, my comment was to make sure we don't remove the xml header, since it's very standard.

Added to parent-level README.
(There are no per-sample "child" READMEs - happy to discuss if that's something you think would be useful.)

nodes.bodyText: N.B: wrong commit name, should be [comments] use proper IDOH pattern
@ace-n  I supper appreciate you taking the time to comment these well. These are great.
we typically don't need ending newline for log messages.
Done.
nice use of optional!

Good catch - will refactor.
(Aside: it looks like Content-Type values are recommended but not required, at least in reponses. So @eamonnmcmanus marking this parameter optional should be fine.)
Why do we have this?  How does it help users?

+  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
+
+  <groupId>com.example.cloud.functions</groupId>

+  <version>1.0.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
+
+  <properties>
+    <maven.compiler.target>11</maven.compiler.target>
+    <maven.compiler.source>11</maven.compiler.source>
+    <kokoro.skipTests>true</kokoro.skipTests> <!-- test children POMs instead -->
+  </properties>
+
+  <!--
+    List subfolders as separate modules, to enable top-level test runs
+    This POM should *not* be inherited by the per-function POMs
+  -->
+  <packaging>pom</packaging>
+  <modules>
+    <module>helloworld</module>
+    <module>http</module>
+    <module>imagemagick</module>
+    <module>slack</module>
+    <module>concepts</module>
+    <module>logging</module>
+    <module>firebase</module>
+    <module>ocr</module>
+  </modules>
+</project>

nodes.bodyText:
this helps user to build and test all functions in one shot. it also allows user to open up functions in the IDE in one shot if i need to.  like i mentioned separately, each sub directory/module is still completely independent.
the parent in the children pom references a published pom, i feel it's good as long as a comment on it's not needed for user.

nodes.bodyText:
@saturnism and I discussed this on Friday - this parent POM lets us run mvn builds across all the samples to verify that all of them work as intended.
(Otherwise, we'd have to run each one individually.)

nodes.bodyText: also discussed in the doc and the call, this causes no harm for the samples. what gets problematic is if the children pom/module refers back to here for configuration, in which case, the children modules can't be built indepedently.

nodes.bodyText:
I'll defer to @lesv for the final decision, but I'm still -1 on this (mostly because I don't like snowflakes).
My concerns are largely mitigated since Ace has already adapted the script + left helpful comments in it and Ray made a good point about it being a one way configuration. However, I don't think we really expect users to run all the tests in a single shot, which means this is only really for us. Our CI doesn't use this, which means there is nothing really stopping someone new adding a sample and not putting it here. So I guess I'd still prefer not to have it, but I'll leave it up to @lesv.

nodes.bodyText:
BTW - it's possible to do this in bash, but it's not exactly the most straightforward thing (mainly because of array-vs-string gotchas):
find */pom.xml | xargs -I {} echo $(pwd)/{} | xargs -I {} dirname {} | xargs -I {} sh -c "cd {} && mvn clean verify"

Kurtis / Les - given that we wouldn't expect customers/contributors to figure the above bash out, would you be open to keeping this parent POM if we added a comment to it like this?
This pom.xml file is kept for testing/Maven compatibility purposes only.

Please DO NOT add dependencies and/or common settings here. The child folders inherit from our `shared-configuration` stored on GitHub instead of this file; cross-POM changes should be added there.

+  http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

+  distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+  WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+  See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+  limitations under the License.
+-->
+
+<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
+    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
+    xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
+  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
+
+  <groupId>com.example.cloud.functions</groupId>
+  <artifactId>functions-snippets</artifactId>
+  <version>1.0.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
+
+  <properties>
+    <maven.compiler.target>11</maven.compiler.target>
+    <maven.compiler.source>11</maven.compiler.source>
+    <kokoro.skipTests>true</kokoro.skipTests> <!-- test children POMs instead -->
+  </properties>
+
+  <!--
+    List subfolders as separate modules, to enable top-level test runs
+    This POM should *not* be inherited by the per-function POMs
+  -->
+  <packaging>pom</packaging>
+  <modules>
+    <module>helloworld</module>
+    <module>http</module>
+    <module>imagemagick</module>
+    <module>slack</module>
+    <module>concepts</module>
+    <module>logging</module>
+    <module>firebase</module>
+    <module>ocr</module>
+  </modules>
+</project>

nodes.bodyText:
FWIW I think this is simpler:
for pom in $(find * -name pom.xml); do (cd $(dirname $pom) && mvn clean verify); done

nodes.bodyText: @ace-n The problem is we don't expect the engineers who follow / maintain to continue to maintain this.  We used to do it.  We stopped because it got overwhelming as the # of samples increased.

nodes.bodyText:
Les, thanks for clarifying.
Since the modules are explicitly specified in this POM, I'm willing to drop this in favor of a programmatic (e.g. bash) solution.
